body:
(IÂ´d say this is more maintenance than governance, in terms of label?)

*I don't think it's a good idea to directly work on master*, simply since it becomes easy to accidentally break the "current clean version".  It's best gitflow practice to have dev, and only merge to master after ensuring that things still work. Typically you would also give master a stronger branch protection than dev.
I prefer the dev/master model, maybe just have more regular pushes from Dec to master?

@fkiraly 
* To clarify, we don't work directly on master, master is read-only (except for admins), people would work on separate branches, but create PR to merge directly into master rather than merging into dev
* PR runs our CI tests which ensure that everything works before we merge anything. That doesn't change. As said, the PR into master runs more comprehensive CI tests than the PR into dev. 
* If something still breaks, you can always revert to a previous commit. 
* The release process is still separate (triggered by tagging) so there's an extra level of protection for releases/distribution. 
* My current impression is that we merge things into dev thinking that it'll be reviewed again before being merged into master and then create a PR with 100+ changes for various contributions that's nearly impossible to review. My proposed workflow would still require two reviews/approvals for every PR (based on our current branch protection rules) but these reviews would be more meaningful now since they focus on particular, understandable changes rather than a collection of 100+ unrelated changes. So our current workflow may make it more likely to merge bad code. 
* Not sure what "best practice" is, many other packages seem to merge directly into master (I've checked SciPy, scikit-learn, TensorFlow). 
* PS: you have to leave some time to find a consensus and call a vote before casting your vote ;-) 

@TonyBagnall 
* In the end, we want more frequent releases and not just more pushes to master, no? Changing the workflow will make our release cycle faster, because I don't have to go through a separate PR for merging everything from dev into master (including reviews, merge conflicts, etc).

> PS: you have to leave some time to find a consensus and call a vote before casting your vote ;-)

Well, I interpreted this as discussing a concrete proposal for change, rather than "let's review our GitFlow model, any suggestions?" - also, was sticking by the voting process we wanted to introduce?

>"best practice" is, many other packages seem to merge directly into master (I've checked SciPy, scikit-learn, TensorFlow).

In the original GitFlow model
https://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/

it is considered a good idea to separate things:
* consolidation of multiple features - a slightly messy endeavour if multiple people are working on a project
* updating the production release, triggering a build

It is also considered good that there is always a branch which only has stable and tested code.

Now one could consider attachment of a tag as the operation that triggers a build, but in the "reduced" model there is no branch were you can be sure that it contains only stable code.

Based on an assortment of situations in which I was tempted to send emails with subject line "don't merge while drunk", I strongly suggest to err on the side of caution here...

>Not sure what "best practice" is, many other packages seem to merge directly into master (I've checked SciPy, scikit-learn, TensorFlow).

sklearn seems to adopt the master/dev/feature GitFlow models, in the form of a feature/dev/release model?

As far as I can see:
* vanilla Gitflow dev corresponds to master on sklearn
* vanilla Gitflow master/release is the newest sklearn release branch - e.g., 0.23.0
* feature branches go into sklearn master and live on forks

Personally, I don't mind master/dev/feature or release/dev/feature, and I'm happy if we call dev master in the second. 

But either is different from just attaching tags, no?
since you bare the load of managing pull requests I'm inclined to do it the way you think best, but I'll discuss it with my guys

>since you bare the load of managing pull requests I'm inclined to do it the way you think best, but I'll discuss it with my guys

I very much second that, in terms of the final decision made, but it won't keep me from disagreeing based on my own opinions :-)

@fkiraly As far as I understand the release branches in scikit-learn, their main purpose is to have a "feature freeze". This allows to add minor changes to a given release (e.g. bug fixes) and to continue to develop major features based on master for the next release. But we don't really have this level of parallel development activity at the moment. For now, working based on master seems to best choice.

>@fkiraly As far as I understand the release branches in scikit-learn, their main purpose is to have a "feature freeze".

Yes, but it also is a suitable replacement for a "true" master branch, in capturing a clean version in a branch, separate from the act of merging and consolidation - so accidental destruction of the clean branch (in the sense of having a non-working most recent commit) is highly inlikely.

*without* the release branches, you wouldnÂ´t have any "safe" branches - thatÂ´s why I am ok with master/dev/features, or release/dev/features, but not with master/features.
